Source   Edit  

This module provides the type definitions that are the foundation of this library. And also some helper functions for constructing those types.

You probably won't be using this unless you are writing something really low-level And also, good luck with that.

Types

ConfigTable = OrderedTable[(string, string), ConfigValue]
Source   Edit   
ConfigValue = object
  case kind*: ConfigValueKind
  of CVNone:
    nil
  of CVInt:
    intVal*: int
  of CVBool:
    boolVal*: bool
  of CVString:
    stringVal*: string
  of CVArray:
    arrayVal*: seq[ConfigValue]
  of CVTable:
    tableVal*: OrderedTable[string, ConfigValue]
  of CVType:
    t*: ConfigValueKind
    child_t*: ConfigValueKind
Source   Edit   
ConfigValueKind = enum
  CVNone, CVInt, CVBool, CVString, CVArray, CVTable, CVType
Source   Edit  

Procs

proc newCValue(value: bool): ConfigValue {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Creates a ConfigValue object of the Boolean kind.

Example:

import iniplus
let
  config = parseString("fav_bool=true")
  value = newCValue(true)

assert config.getValue("","fav_bool") == value
Source   Edit

Creates a ConfigValue object of the Int kind

Example:

assert config.getValue("","fav_number") == value
Source   Edit   
proc newCValue(value: seq[ConfigValue]): ConfigValue {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}

Creates a ConfigValue object of the Sequence kind.

This function is similar to the varargs-based function, except it takes a sequence of ConfigValue objects as an argument

Example:

import iniplus
let
  config = parseString("favorites=[\"John\", \"Katie\", true]")
  value = newCValue(
    @[
      newCValue("John"),
      newCValue("Katie"),
      newCValue(true)
    ]
  )

assert config.getArray("","favorites")[0] == value.arrayVal[0]
assert config.getArray("","favorites")[1] == value.arrayVal[1]
assert config.getArray("","favorites")[2] == value.arrayVal[2]
Source   Edit

Creates a ConfigValue object of the String kind

Example:

import iniplus

  config = parseString("fav_person=\"John\"")
  value = newCValue("John")

assert config.getValue("","fav_person") == value

proc newCValue(value: varargs[ConfigValue]): ConfigValue {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}
Creates a ConfigValue object of the Sequence kind.

Example:

import iniplus
let
  config = parseString("favorites=[\"John\", \"Katie\", \"Isaac\"]")
  value = newCValue(
    newCValue("John"),
    newCValue("Katie"),
    newCValue("Isaac")
  )

assert config.getStringArray("","favorites")[0] == value.arrayVal[0]
assert config.getStringArray("","favorites")[1] == value.arrayVal[1]
assert config.getStringArray("","favorites")[2] == value.arrayVal[2]
Source   Edit   
proc newCValue[T](val: seq[T]): ConfigValue

Creates a ConfigValue object of the Sequence kind.

This function is similar to the varargs-based function, except it takes a sequence of ConfigValue objects.

It's not possible to mix and match different data types with this procedure. If you want to mix different data types into your array, then you must convert each item one-by-one using either varargs or a sequenceÂ·

Example:

import iniplus
let
  config = parseString("my_favorite_people=[\"John\", \"Katie\", \"Mark\"]")
  value = newCValue(@[
      "John",
      "Katie",
      "Mark"
    ]
  )

# Yes, this is a mess. Just use the regular getArray() procedure if you want an easier time dealing with arrays.
assert config.getStringArray("","my_favorite_people")[0] == value.arrayVal[0].stringVal
assert config.getStringArray("","my_favorite_people")[1] == value.arrayVal[1].stringVal
assert config.getStringArray("","my_favorite_people")[2] == value.arrayVal[2].stringVal
Source   Edit
